title.value: Restoring the missing person to personalized medicine and precision psychiatry
title.justification: The title of the paper is clearly stated at the beginning of the document.
title.quote: Restoring the missing person to personalized medicine and precision psychiatry

extractions.description: This paper discusses the current limitations of precision psychiatry, which predominantly focuses on biological parameters, and proposes an ecosocial approach that integrates person-centered care by considering phenomenological, psychological, behavioral, social, structural, and cultural dimensions.

type.justification: The paper focuses on proposing a new theoretical framework for precision psychiatry by integrating multiple dimensions like psychosocial, phenomenological, and cultural aspects.
type.quote: In this paper, we review the limitations of precision psychiatry arguing that it cannot reach its goal if it does not include core elements of the processes that give rise to psychopathological states, which include the agency and experience of the person.

name.justification: The paper is primarily concerned with the field of Psychiatry, focusing on improving precision psychiatry through a multidimensional approach.
name.quote: To address the limitations of current approaches, we suggest that the frameworks and research program of precision psychiatry need to be supplemented with additional constructs and measures that can situate it in relation to the social contexts and experiences that are of central concern in clinical care.

name.justification: The paper also delves into the role of neuroscience in precision psychiatry.
name.quote: In precision psychiatry, the characterization of individuals is currently done mainly using biological parameters similar to those employed in other areas of medicine.

name.justification: The paper mentions the application and limitations of computational psychiatry in the scope of precision psychiatry.
name.quote: Precision psychiatry has inherited biases from computational psychiatry, such as its over-emphasis on decision-making using idealized tasks derived from economics and game theory.
